provenance: [Mathieu Néouze, Paris, until 2020; to Weisberg]; Yvonne and Gabriel Weisberg, Minneapolis
signed: Lower right corner, black ink: [Japanese inscription] / Bando
text: Painted shortly after the Japanese-born Toshio Bando left Paris for the quieter suburb of Pierrefitte-sur-Seine, Caravan in Front of a Hill captures the tension between urban modernity and life in the banlieues, or suburbs, of Paris after World War I. While his Parisian contemporaries were preoccupied with life in the city, Bando turned his attention to the lives of itinerant families and laborers living just beyond its limits. The scene is filled with quiet activity: figures gather near makeshift caravans at the base of gently rising hills, their world bounded by the fortified walls of the old city on one side and by the rural landscape on the other. The painting’s layered composition and subdued palette reveal both a sensitivity to place and a subtle social awareness, reflecting Bando’s interest in how ordinary life unfolds amid shifting economic and cultural landscapes.
title: Caravan in Front of a Hill (La caravane devant la colline)
